abstracts.cdata!:
The project outcome is rated
            satisfactory, with project sustainability likely primarily
            because the Local Government Development Fund and the
            decentralization laws are now in operation, discretionary
            transfers have been outlawed, municipalities continue to
            implement more measures to increase their own resources and
            increase their capacity to plan and execute projects, and
            many mayors are being re-elected and using longer-term
            planning horizons, including privatization plans. Both World
            Bank and Borrower performances are adjudged satisfactory.
            Lessons learned include the following: To the degree lenders
            do not identify all affected groups and work with them to
            see the "win-win" aspects of such projects as this
            one, success may be limited. In the early phase of this
            project, there were several instances of both central-local
            and intra-local conflicts related to this problem. It should
            be made clear that revenue-sharing practices is not a goal
            in decentralization and municipal development projects; few
            sub-national entities can totally survive on their own
            resources. National contracting issues had to be addressed
            at the project level which lowered considerably the
            probability of success. Use of revenue-sharing funds as
            sub-loan guarantees is a good device for first-generation
            municipal lending operations; however, sub-national
            borrowers and lenders need to quickly move to instruments
            which more closely link investments with their associated
            costs, benefits, and risks.
